linesOfText.text:
"Happy birthday, Caleb!" everyone
shouted at a boy with curly hair and freckles. The excited boy sat in his
wheelchair looking over his chocolate cake, while eight candles burned brightly.

"Make a wish," his Mom whispered in his ear.

Caleb looked up in the air to think to himself. Finally after several seconds he
decided on one wish. He took a deep breath, and then blew out every candle on the cake.

"What did you wish for?" his friend Benny asked.
"That I could fly," he said with excitement.
"YOU CAN'T FLY, CALEB," Benny shouted in shock, "no one can fly. You're
crazy!"

"Yes I can," the birthday boy responded.
"Okay kids, get a slice of cake," Caleb's Mom announced.

Caleb decided that he wanted to eat his cake in his club house. With his cake in
his lap, he wheeled himself to his club house as his dog, Ozzy followed behind him.

Several blue balloons tied to a tree swayed from a small breeze, catching his
attention. "I wish I could fly," he mumbled to Ozzy. "That would be so much fun."

He then wheeled himself towards the tree to stare at the
round balloons. Caleb started to untie two balloons from the
tree, holding them carefully in his hands.

"I wish I could fly," he repeated.

For a few seconds he waited quietly, but then grew
grew disappointed when nothing happened. A breeze
brushed against his face, which made him open his eyes.
All of a sudden his eyes widened. The blue balloons
were carrying him away!

"Look at me," he hollered, while he flew over his backyard. "I can
fly!"

Ozzy began jumping up and down and barking.

His belly became tickled from being excited. As he was staring at all of
the houses below him, he did not notice that he was heading into
some tall trees. The balloons carried him right through the tree
tops, causing Caleb to get leaves inside of his
mouth and in his hair.

"Gross," he said as he spit out the leaves
from his mouth.

A woodpecker took notice of the boy and flew right
next to him. Several times the woodpecker
flew around the two balloons. Finally,
the woodpecker landed on his curly
hair. Caleb wiggled his arms to try to
get the woodpecker off of his head,
but the bird didn't budge one bit.

Without warning, the woodpecker started to peck at his head. "Ouch," he
shouted. "Stop doing that, I'm not a tree," he scolded the bird. He shook his head
several times, this time causing the bird to fly away.

Not paying any attention to his whereabouts, he drifted over the city zoo. His
eyes read a sign in huge, red letters: ALLIGATOR.

With each and every stride, the balloons hovered closer to the pond. The water
was green, which didn't allow him to see any alligators.

Caleb opened his eyes widely as he sailed over the pond. He gave off a deep sigh.
The alligators in the pond were only little babies. Three green alligators rolled around in
the water, wiggling their tails as Caleb flew over them.

"That was a close call," Caleb
said out of breath, while he
gazed below his feet.
"They're only babies,"
he laughed.

As he looked over his shoulder to say good-bye to the alligators, a gust of wind carried
him across the chimpanzee exhibit. The chimpanzees started swinging from tree to tree.
When Caleb sailed through some vines, a chimpanzee stuck a piece of banana into his mouth.

"Thank you, Mr. Chimpanzee, I was getting hungry,"
he said with his mouth full of banana.

The blue balloons sailed away from the
chimpanzee exhibit, heading towards a
green wall that resembled a giant. For a
few seconds he thought he was going to
hit the wall, but slowly the balloons started
carrying him over the wall.

Some tall giraffes greeted him. Their ears began to wiggle as Caleb circled
around their heads. He hovered in the air, causing one giraffe to sniff the balloons.

"CACHOO!" the giraffe sneezed, which caused Caleb to fly backwards through
the blue sky.

"Whoa," he shouted as he flew through a patch of white clouds in the sky.

Without notice, he started to hear some strange sounds, but because he was in the
clouds he could not see anything.

Everywhere he looked, all he could see were the clouds that looked like
white cotton candy. "ZOOM," he heard loudly in the distance.

Like a flash of lightning, a jumbo jet soared through the clouds. The
force of the passing jet caused the boy to spin in circles.
"Ahh!" he shouted as he kept spinning round and round.

He closed his eyes because he grew dizzy from all of the spinning, but he still
managed to laugh from the wild ride. When he opened his eyes he saw that he was flying
back towards land.

"Gosh I'm tired," he said. "This has been an exciting day."

From the corner of his eye he could see his house. He tried to wiggle his
arms to steer himself towards his house, but the balloons went in the
opposite direction.

"How do I get home?"

Though he enjoyed flying, Caleb started to get tired. The sight of his house began
to get smaller. He kept looking over his shoulders, staring behind his back, hoping a
breeze would push him towards his house.

Caleb held onto the strings of the
blue balloons tightly. "I wish I could get
back home to my birthday party," he
said as he stared at the two balloons.

As he tried to think of ways to get back home,
two white ducks landed on the balloons to catch
a ride. They quacked a few times.

"Can you please help me get home?" the boy asked the ducks.

"Quack, quack, quack," the two ducks said.

The balloons stopped drifting away; instead they seemed to be lowering over the
tree tops from the weight of the chubby ducks. A breeze pushed the balloons over
Caleb's house.



"That's it, we're getting closer to my house," he said excitedly.

"Quack, quack, quack," the ducks said again.

Caleb's feet began to touch the leaves on the tree tops. He was almost
home. Then all of a sudden he heard a loud noise. "POP!" went the
balloons. This caused the ducks to fly away. He closed his eyes as
he floated softly onto the seat of his wheelchair.

"Caleb, it's time to play pin the tail on the donkey," his Mom shouted.
He opened his eyes when he heard the familiar voice of his Mom. He was home!

Around his club house he could see more blue balloons, but not the popped ones he used to fly. They
were nowhere to be found. Ozzy sat in front of him with his tail wagging and barking, and then rushed to
Caleb to lick his face. Caleb wasn't sure if he had daydreamed everything, or if he actually did fly.

"I'm coming, Mom" he yelled.

Caleb's Mom opened her arms and gave him a big hug as Ozzy
ran around the two of them jumping up in the air excitedly.

"Mom, this is the best birthday
party I've ever had!" he said. "Thank
you so much!"

"You're welcome, Caleb," his Mom said. "Did your wish come true?"

"It sure did!" he said. "This has been the best day of my life!"
